children.subject: I have not taken stat 140 also, can I like go through it in the summer?

If you have taken classes like stat 134 and 140, you should be fine.

EECS 126 is not essential, and stat 140 prepares you roughly the same.

I have not take189 but I am taking 126 right now, I would say 126 is not necessary for 189 but would definitely be helpful for performing well in 189. Some people who have taken 189 before 126 also commented 126 is even harder than 189, making 126 possibly the hardest EECS upper div at Berkeley. Professor Sahai also said 126 will not necessarily prepare you for 189.

history.content: I've taken 126 and am in 189 right now. As far as probability goes I really wouldn't think of 126 as a prerequisite for 189. I think for most people 70 might be enough (assuming you put in a lot of work and understood probability well). However, 126 definitely makes your life easier in a sense and there is some overlap (Decision theory, MLE etc). If you feel shaky on probability definitely take 126 or stat 140 but otherwise I would say that EECS127 is more "important". One thing to add is that the course might change between professors, all of my observations are based on Schewchuk's version of the course.

children.subject:
Sure thanks , 

       Will going over the all the probability related material be useful?

I would just directly read through the CS 189 notes over the summer. You can find them online here. Try to go through Notes 1-4 first, paying careful attention to the derivations/proofs (try to write out all the steps in extreme detail, ask yourself why every statement is true, etc.). You can also find previous semesters' lectures via course capture. If you find doing this extremely hard, then maybe consider taking some of the prerequisite courses. Repeat this deep reading for as many notes as possible. Try to google things that you don't know, and attempt some previous exams/homework problems.

If you actually spend 3-4 weeks doing this (at least one deep read through all the notes before the semester starts and 1-2 previous exams already solved), you would be in extremely good shape for the semester. Specific probability questions should arise as you read/solve examples from the notes, so you can address them then. Some would argue that this is overkill, but if you really want to get a good grade in the course and understand the material, I would consider doing this.

I agree with all these other comments. However, "necessary to pass the class" is different from "necessary to really understand the concepts." Especially if you take it in the fall, the section on EM will feel very confusing (at least for me it did) since I didn't have a strong understanding of continuous probability and couldn't really work with conditional distributions well. Also other sections on MLE, MAP, Naive Bayes, GDA, and QDA will require some work to understand, and you will be very disadvantaged compared to people who have already seen these concepts before or have a stronger probability background.

Moreover, Sahai (who is teaching it in the fall) really likes to emphasize understanding over memorization. So if you try to just regurgitate formulas from the notes and learn by doing practice exams (which is a valid strategy for some classes), you will probably not do very well (also since the bank of Sahai-style previous exams is smaller). An example is that all the EM examples in the notes were done with Gaussians, but on the final exam we had to derive the update rule with the multinomial distribution, something that would be hard to do without experience in probability. However he does curve well, so the grading distribution will probably be favorable for you.

I'm not sure what the best course of action would be (perhaps delaying CS 189 a semester to take one of EE 126/127, perhaps just taking CS 189 and filling in the gaps as they arise), but hopefully this advice is useful.

history.content:
Hi guys,

         So I am taking CS189 in fall 2020. (I would have  taken CS188(Summer),MATH110 (taking right now )  .So I am not taking EE126 and I have heard CS189 is pretty hard. I want to prepare for it in the summer. Can anybody who has taken CS189 without taking EE126 give any tips on how to prepare for CS189. Also I am applied math major(most probably) .

                                                         Thanks!!
